@system wrote:

I had no intentions to show how smart I am (I don’t even think I am that smart myself).

But it is always fun to know about the inner workings, and why things happen as they do. I never really said he must follow my guidelines. And for when the time comes, when he wants to make something much bigger, it is always good to handle things more properly.

If he himself thinks it has gone a little bit too far, I think he can say that for himself. And if so is the case, I appology for any inconvenience.

item.title: My super noob sum calculator :D
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

Well it’s certainly better than Hello World for a first program.

Perhaps try now adding your other maths operators:
-Multiplication
-Subtraction
-Division

You can achieve this by learning “If statements” I’m not sure if you’re aware of them yet, but they should be the next thing you’ll be learning. All in all a calculator is a great program to write when learning because you can steadily just build it up until it has abilities to work out things such as quadratic equations and a fancy GUI or other complex mathematics. Obviously start at the bottom and work your way up.

Here’s something that may help: http://tutorials.noclip.org/Videos/java/3/3.htm

Read full topic

item.title: My super noob sum calculator :D
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

Yes, that is exactly what I mean.

-Chaos-, I just noticed another thing…

The following does work, but it is totally unnecessary. As you can see, you put a “+” at the start of the String:

System.out.print(+int1+" + "+int2+" = "+int3+"");

So, to make it look nicer, you could just remove that “+”. And also, you could use space between each and every arithmetic operator and their following values etc.

If you don’t know what the arithmetic operators are, here they come:
+, -, *, / and %.

Read full topic

item.title: My super noob sum calculator :D
item.dc:creator: @_cake _cake
item.description:
@_cake wrote:

lul I have no fkn clue what you’re saying so I’m going to pretend I can prove you wrong.
Isn’t it just:

bipush/sipush#FIRSTNUMBER
bipush/sipush #SECONDNUMBER
iadd

and the bipush/sipush instructions can also be an iload or other shit.

edit:
wait I get it, you’re saying that there would be no new field allocated to hold the value of the iadd… hence saving memory.

Read full topic

item.title: My super noob sum calculator :D
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

Not quite everything else, pizza pie. If you are declaring a constant, you usually first of all use “private static final” or any other modifier (where modifier means “private” in this case (could be “public” and “protected” aswell)). Then when naming it, you capitalize all letters in it, and you also must initialize its value. A constant should be constant, and not be changable.

Here is an example:

private static final String LOCAL_INTERNET_PROTOCOL = "127.0.0.1";

As you can see, I also put underscores between each and every word in the name, that is also mentioned in the Java naming conventions.

There is another thing I can point out in your source code, -Chaos-. You don’t really need the variable named “int3”.

Now, just do it like this instead:

System.out.println("Your answer is " + (int1 + int2));

It does take up less memory, since the variable “int3” would create a new reference within the memory, pointing towards both “int1” and “int2” as one summation.

Read full topic

item.description:
@pizza_pie wrote:

Just a note, you only capitalize every word of a ClassName. For everything else, you use lower case firstWords.

(not spelling mistakes, take a hint)

item.title: My super noob sum calculator :D
item.dc:creator: @Chaos -Chaos-
item.description:
@Chaos wrote:

well yup i recently got into java and ya i know its noob but here it is

[code=javascript]import java.util.*;
public class Calculator {

public static void main(String[] args)
{
Scanner Input = new Scanner(System.in);

int  int1;
int  int2;
int  int3;
String UserIn;


    System.out.print("Whats your name?");
    UserIn = Input.next();


    System.out.println("Hello "+UserIn+" Welcome To My Calculator");

    System.out.print("Please Insert The First Number :");
    int1 = Input.nextInt();

    System.out.print("Please Enter Your Second Number :");
    int2 = Input.nextInt();

    int3= int1+int2;

    System.out.println("Your Answer Is "+int3);

    System.out.println("/////////////////////////////////////////");

    System.out.print(+int1+" + "+int2+" = "+int3+"");

}

}
[/code]

Read full topic
